ArticleTitle.sentence: Association of alterations in NF-kappa B moieties with HIV type 1 proviral latency in certain monocytic cells.

event.clue: Association of alterations in NF-kappa B moieties with HIV type 1 proviral latency in certain monocytic cells.

AbstractText.sentence: Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) replication is controlled by a complex array of virally encoded and cellular proteins.

event.clue: Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) replication is controlled by a complex array of virally encoded and cellular proteins.
Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) replication is controlled by a complex array of virally encoded and cellular proteins.

AbstractText.sentence: A wide spectrum of levels of HIV-1 expression have been demonstrated in various cells, both in cell culture and in vivo.

event.clue: A wide spectrum of levels of HIV-1 expression have been demonstrated in various cells, both in cell culture and in vivo.

AbstractText.sentence: Molecular mechanisms leading to restricted HIV-1 replication may differ between certain cell types.

event.clue: Molecular mechanisms leading to restricted HIV-1 replication may differ between certain cell types.
Molecular mechanisms leading to restricted HIV-1 replication may differ between certain cell types.

AbstractText.sentence: It is now demonstrated that HIV-1 proviral latency in the monocytic cell line U1, in which only extremely low levels of HIV-1 expression are detected in the baseline unstimulated state, is associated with alterations in nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kappa B) moieties demonstrated in these cells by electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) and in situ UV cross-linking studies.

event.clue: It is now demonstrated that HIV-1 proviral latency in the monocytic cell line U1, in which only extremely low levels of HIV-1 expression are detected in the baseline unstimulated state, is associated with alterations in nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kappa B) moieties demonstrated in these cells by electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) and in situ UV cross-linking studies.

It is now demonstrated that HIV-1 proviral latency in the monocytic cell line U1, in which only extremely low levels of HIV-1 expression are detected in the baseline unstimulated state, is associated with alterations in nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kappa B) moieties demonstrated in these cells by electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) and in situ UV cross-linking studies.

It is now demonstrated that HIV-1 proviral latency in the monocytic cell line U1, in which only extremely low levels of HIV-1 expression are detected in the baseline unstimulated state, is associated with alterations in nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kappa B) moieties demonstrated in these cells by electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSAs) and in situ UV cross-linking studies.

AbstractText.sentence: A predominance of p50 NF-kappa B moieties and possibly p50 homodimers or closely related species, rather than the p50-p56 heterodimer of NF-kappa B that is the predominant NF-kappa B species in most T lymphocytic and monocytic cells, is demonstrated in the nuclei of U1 cells.

event.clue: A predominance of p50 NF-kappa B moieties and possibly p50 homodimers or closely related species, rather than the p50-p56 heterodimer of NF-kappa B that is the predominant NF-kappa B species in most T lymphocytic and monocytic cells, is demonstrated in the nuclei of U1 cells.

A predominance of p50 NF-kappa B moieties and possibly p50 homodimers or closely related species, rather than the p50-p56 heterodimer of NF-kappa B that is the predominant NF-kappa B species in most T lymphocytic and monocytic cells, is demonstrated in the nuclei of U1 cells.

AbstractText.sentence: This pattern of NF-kappa B-related moieties differs from the latently infected T lymphocytic cell line ACH-2, and from the U937 monocytic line, the parental cell line of the U1 cellular clone.
As such, these data suggest that different proximal mechanisms may lead to restricted HIV-1 replication in various cell types.

event.clue: As such, these data suggest that different proximal mechanisms may lead to restricted HIV-1 replication in various cell types.
